identificationModule.briefTitle: Motor Evoked Potential in the Affected Upper Limb Predicts the Potential of Motor Recovery in Subacute Stroke Patients
identificationModule.officialTitle: Motor Evoked Potential in the Affected Upper Limb Predicts the Potential of Motor Recovery in Subacute Stroke Patients

descriptionModule.briefSummary: Stroke is the third common cause of adult disability in dveloped countries. Early identification of the potential for motor recovery is important to avoid 'learned disuse' and to initiate appropriate therapy with achievable goals. The current cohort study focuses on those patients with SAFE \<8 and using motor evoked potentials (MEPs) to improve on prognostication of upper limb motor recovery among subacute stroke patients in a local stroke population.

armGroups.label: Presence of motor evoked potentials
armGroups.description: Those patients with Shoulder Abduction and Finger Extension (SAFE) score \<8/10 with the presence of motor evoked potentials elicited by TMS over the ipsilesional motor cortex
interventionNames: Diagnostic Test: MEPs induced by TMS

armGroups.label: absence of motor evoked potentials
armGroups.description: Those patients with Shoulder Abduction and Finger Extension (SAFE) score \<8/10 with the absence of motor evoked potentials elicited by TMS over the ipsilesional motor cortex
interventionNames: Diagnostic Test: MEPs induced by TMS

interventions.name: MEPs induced by TMS
interventions.description: Using TMS induced MEPs over motor cortex of the affected side to predict motor recovery potentials

primaryOutcomes.timeFrame: Change of Baseline Action Research Arm Test at 12 weeks post-stroke

eligibilityModule.eligibilityCriteria:
Inclusion Criteria:

* First stroke with hemiparesis or hemiplegia with SAFE \<8

Exclusion Criteria:

* contra-indication to TMS or MRI, history of seizure, pregnancy and mentally unfit to understand the consent
